So this breaks down into a couple questions, which are: will a ruling on the charges come before the deadline, and will the decision be to convict. The second question is basically a freebie, 100% yes. It's a show trial and he's been tried and convicted for similar crimes twice before, and the acquittal rate in Russian criminal trials is hilariously low, 0.25% as of 2019 (https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/russia-justice-system-low-acquittal-rate-uk-crown-court-a8935016.html). Previous cases seem to have been geared towards discrediting him and having the conviction bar him from running for public offices, both of which the Kremlin would still have an interest in. If a ruling is brought, it's unlikely that it would be to acquit an enemy of the state for crimes similar to ones he's already been convicted of, especially when acquittal is absurdly rare in trials in general. The practice that the Russian legal system seems to prefer to acquittals is suspension of prison sentences (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suspended_sentence#Russia) like Navalny received in his previous cases. If charges are brought it's almost certain that they'll result in a conviction, with any mitigation done through a sentence suspension. Most of this hinges on whether the charges will come at all, and if they do whether they and a trial will come before the deadline. Charges haven't technically even been brought yet, only a criminal probe opened. Navalny has a couple cases as possible reference points for time from charge to verdict too. In the 2012 Kirovles case, charges were brought on July 30, 2012, and the trial was on April 17 2013, 8.5 months later. In the Yves Rocher case, the initial claim was filed December 14 2012, charges brought October 29 2013, and Navalny (and his brother) were sentenced on December 30 2014, a gap of 14 months between charges and sentencing. This is another investigation for financial crimes, so I’d imagine the time from charges to trial should be somewhere in that range. A very quick/rushed trial wouldn’t align well with how Russia has treated Navalny thus far. Russia has at least been pretending to follow the law this whole time, like they didn’t stop his plane from exiting the country to Germany, and his past trials were procedurally normal, but there’s no guarantee that that will continue considering how high-profile the case is. However, if they want to jail him, they have the option of reinstating his suspended prison sentence from 2014 for violation of parole, which they’re currently in the process of doing. If they want to bring charges before the next parliamentary election, they can focus on the foreign agent and defamation of a WWII veteran narratives that have more emotional punch. They don’t need new charges to be brought, much less a formal conviction to come. According to Navalny they’ve already seized his and his orgs’ bank accounts, presumably outwardly justified by the fraud investigation, so they probably don’t need to step that up. The argument in favor of conviction before the deadline is that they’ll want to convict him of more crimes to discredit him before the parliamentary elections coming up in September, similar to how they’ve brought charges before elections in the past. Financial crimes, especially ones similar to what he accuses other politicians of, could be more “normal” charges to complement the more emotional/outlandish foreign agent and defamation charges. They could rationalize the very quick timeline by saying the crimes were so obvious they didn’t need more time to investigate, and the trial was expedited because he’s a threat to the public. In the past Putin has refused to even say his name to avoid giving him publicity, but that has definitely changed recently with state media bashing him constantly. Acting swiftly and deviating from past procedure could serve to intimidate others as well, which the Kremlin clearly wants to do, by showing that they won’t be bound by their typical standards in squashing dissent like this. He’s already been barred from running on past convictions, but adding a fundraising fraud conviction could further justify that decision as well. Alternatively, this could be a way of targeting his non-profit orgs and restricting their activities, by painting them as a piggy bank for a criminal currently in prison. The weakness of those arguments is that they could achieve most of the same goals by simply bringing charges, not convicting. They can “legally” keep him imprisoned on other charges as they are now, or keep him imprisoned for the fraud charges for up to a year after charges are brought. The can support the bar on running based on the fraud charges or the ongoing associated investigation, if he’s somehow out of prison come election season. They can target his non-profit orgs by labelling them as foreign agents, which they’ve already done in order to restrict their activities, and can presumably seize their assets as part of an investigation, which Navalny claims they’ve already done as well. If the Kremlin is still trying to appear outwardly fair and just like they have in the past, then rushing a trial would also risk looking corrupt. Depending on procedure it may also give Navalny a platform, which he’s been good with in the past, notably asking the judge if she has any recipes for pickled gherkins since discussing the law is pointless. Denying him the right to speak in his trial would again risk looking corrupt. Another possibility that is important to consider is if Navalny dies in the meantime. This is the more extreme intimidation option the Kremlin could consider, and they’ve already tried a couple months ago. Russia can do posthumous trials like they did for Magnitsky, but the trial would almost certainly come much later than August of this year. Magnitsky’s posthumous trial came more than two years after his death, presumably because doing a trial right after his death would’ve made the case look much worse. If he dies the chance of a trial coming for these charges is very very low. Overall, a lot would need to fall into place for a conviction on these charges to come this soon. They need to bring charges and do a trial all within a very short time frame, and the closer we get to the deadline the lower the chance that charges will result in a trial by the deadline. If we reach May or June with no charges the chance would probably be near zero. Rushing a trial on these charges would deviate from past behavior in a way that isn’t optimal for most ends as far as I can see. The Kremlin has been deviating from past behavior recently, and there is a world where they may want a conviction, but other outcomes are all more likely.
